About

Amemiya-daiku

Amemiya-daiku is located in Yamanashi-prefecture, Enzan, Japan. The company's foreman is Amemiya Kunihiro. The company focuses on traditional Japanese carpentry techniques. Techniques such as squaring logs with the Japanese broadaxe and adze, cutting large timbers in boards with the wide bladed-ripsaw and the traditional way of assembling the frame using the mortise and tenon and more complicated joints. The objective is to build sustainable environmental friendly homes. This by using as much hand tools as possible, manual labor and ancient knowledge and skills. The homes are not only friendly for their surroundings but also for their inhabitants. By living close to nature, the true meaning of a home can come true: comforting peoples mind. Local materials such as trees and earth are used. This in order to keep the ecological footprint as low as possible from the beginning of the building process.

The company offers: small huts were you can experience an outer space - minka reform and renovation - free earthquake resistance diagnosis.

History

1969 Born in Koushuu (graduated from Nichikawa Senior Highschool).
1989 Starting his apprenticeship as a carpenter by his father Amemiya Kunio.
1999 Becoming an independent carpenter, Amemiya-daiku is born.
2004 Winning the prefectural skills competition of Yamanashi.
2007 Taking part in the reconstruction of 1600 year old skills at the Yamanashi 'kai choushizuka kofun'.
2007 Building a large Torii in Germany with craftsmen from 5 different countries.
2008 Taking part in recording traditional skills for the ministry of culture of France and the Takenaka Carpentry Tools museum.
2009 Being acknowledged as an 'expert of the wood' by the National Land Afforestation Promotion Organization.
2010 Involved in investigating Joumon-era lifestyle at the Ishikawa prefectural Iwaki historic ruins (splitting timber and stone axe hewing).
2010 Hosting the 'Chiisa-na Kezurokai in Ichinose' in Ichinose.
